A manager’s review of the effectiveness of controls within their area of responsibility and the involvement of each level of management in certifying the control environment within their area is conducive to identifying risks or deﬁciencies at all levels. b. Control deﬁciency

A situation caused by the design or operation of a control not allowing management or employees, in the normal course performing their assigned functions, to prevent or detect misstatements on a timely basis. c. Corrective action
An action taken to correct identiﬁed deﬁciencies, produces recommended improvements, or demonstrates that control ﬁndings are either invalid or do not warrant audited action. d. Internal controls

Processes and procedures put into place by ment to help an organization operate efficiently and effectively to its objectives. Internal (management) control is an integral component an organization’s management that provides unmodiﬁed assurance that the following objectives are being achieved: a) Effectiveness and efficiency of operations. b) Reliability of ﬁnancial reporting. c) Compliance with applicable laws and regulations. e. Material weakness

A deﬁciency, or combination of deﬁciencies, in internal control over ﬁnancial reporting, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the entity’s ﬁnancial will not be prevented, or detected and corrected, on a timely basis. f. Modiﬁed assurance

Informed judgment by the head of an based upon all available information, that the internal controls in place may not be adequate to address the problems identiﬁed in the memorandum. This opinion is based on the number of identiﬁed or the seriousness of the problems. g. Unmodiﬁed assurance

Informed judgment by the head of an tion, based upon all available information, that the internal controls in place adequately protect the resources and ensure mission completion. Unmodiﬁed assurance recognizes that the cost of controls should not exceed the beneﬁts derived from them. h. Remediation plan

A plan to achieve FFMIA compliance when an agency’s annual review determines their ﬁnancial management cannot prepare required ﬁnancial statements and reports, cannot reliable and timely ﬁnancial information for managing operations, and cannot account for assets, all in accordance with federal accounting standards and the USSGL. i. Signiﬁcant deﬁciency
A deﬁciency, or a combination of deﬁciencies, internal control that is less severe than a material weakness, yet enough to merit the attention of those charged with governance.
